newsitem.title: USA: U.S. faults Arafat, Netanyahu on charges.
newsitem.headline: U.S. faults Arafat, Netanyahu on charges.

text.p: The United States on Thursday criticised Israeli and Palestinian leaders for attacking each other publicly after Secretary of State Madeleine Albright urged both sides to revive a spirit of partnership on peace.
State Department spokesman James Rubin noted that Albright, in a speech on Wednesday, "talked a lot about the importance of partnership and building partnership if we're going to build peace."
"And we do not regard the statements that (Palestinian) Chairman (Yasser) Arafat made in this regard as helpful," he told a news briefing.

Arafat was quoted in an Israeli newspaper as saying measures imposed by Israel against Palestinians since a suicide bombing last week amounted to a declaration of war, and warned he was preparing accordingly.
"Netanyahu has declared war on us and we have to prepare for what will come. The situation is serious," Arafat was quoted as saying.
Rubin said "to the extent that (Arafat's statement) is ... interpreted as meaning battle with Israel, we regard them as counterproductive. And we think they should not be made."

He stressed that Arafat and his Palestinian Authority have committed themselves to a peace settlement with Israel and therefore "should refrain from ... statements that cast doubt on the peace that they have committed themselves to."
Rubin was also asked about reports that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused the Palestinian Authority of behaving "like a regime facilitating terror, like Iran or Iraq or Libya."
"It is hard to fathom how one could compare Chairman Arafat to Colonel (Muammar) Gaddafi," Rubin told reporters.

"Chairman Arafat was on the White House lawn with the president. He signed a peace agreement with the Israelis. We regard him as a partner in our effort to find peace in the Middle East," he said, adding:

Aside from closing the border between Israel and the Palestinian self-rule areas, which stops trade and keeps thousands of Palestinians from jobs in Israel, Israel's treasury has frozen transfer of VAT and customs duties it owes the Palestinians.
Albright has been trying to broker an agreement under which Israel would agree to return the money if Palestinians take specific steps to crackdown on terrorism, U.S. officials say.
